text.sentence: Funding model for first dropdown isn't broken; it's just different than originally envisioned: The MLP was created to be the low cost equity funding vehicle for the Columbia Pipeline complex which has a backlog of dollar eight+ billion of spending on modernization and growth opportunities.

Through close on eleven/four, the units have declined ~thirty eight percent from their dollar twenty three IPO price, reflecting a dual slate of investor concerns, specifically, Will CPPL be able to deliver on its targeted distribution growth rate of twenty percent per annum?

The concerns are deeply intertwined: if the funding model is broken, the MLP will not be able to grow, resulting in the equity cost of capital moving higher, which in turn impedes the MLP's ability to grow.

Parent is committed in their support for the MLP's twenty percent growth: On Tuesday's earnings call, management reiterated its distribution growth guidance as well as its intention to use CPPL equity as the primary source of external financing.
With guidance unchanged, we set out to identify what might need to happen in order for the company to make good on its commitments.

On paper, we are able to make the numbers work, but remain cautious because a successful outcome could remain highly contingent upon a number of factors, some of which remain outside of the company's control .
We think the first steps to a solution are going to be a mix of lower equity issuance at the LP, parent taking back the units, and a lower multiple for the first drop.
While this may be more advantageous for the LP than the GP in the short term, it may be a good solution in the long run for the GP if it does fix CPPL to be a more viable funding vehicle.
We lower our price target for CPPL to dollar twenty, and our price target for CPGX to dollar twenty four.
Unchanged For a full list of our ratings, price target and earnings changes in this report, please see table on page two.

U.S. Diversified Natural Gas Columbia Pipeline Group, Inc. Valuation Methodology: Our dollar twenty four price target is predicated on a sum of the parts: one) dollar five.eight billion for CPGX's value of OpCo; two) dollar nine hundred thirty six million for the LP units it holds of CPPL; and three) dollar four.two billion for the GP of CPPL less dollar three.four billion of debt, divided by three hundred seventeen.six million shares.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Price Target: Customer concentration, commodity exposure, credit risk, regulatory risk, acquisition risk, event risk, and capital markets risk.
U.S. MLPs Columbia Pipeline Partners LP Valuation Methodology: Our dollar twenty four price target is predicated on our two thousand sixteene distribution of dollar .eighty

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Price Target: Customer concentration, commodity exposure, credit risk, regulatory risk, acquisition risk, event risk, and capital markets risk.

Barclays | Columbia Pipeline The MLP was created to be the low cost equity funding vehicle for the Columbia complex, so driving accretive acquisitions is key: First, we assume that in order to break the circular reference in the growth/cost of capital conundrum, CPPL is able to buy its first incremental equity interest in OpCo at eleven.x,
lower than the look through value implied by the partnership's current trading level, and lower than what we think an entity growing EBITDA at twenty percent p.a. should rationally sell for.
We think this is one of the few levers within management's control, and wouldn't be surprised to see CPGX make this one time concession to signal its support of CPPL to the market.

Support by the parent for the first drop should alleviate concerns that CPPL won't deliver the twenty percent growth and that the funding model isn't broken, setting the stage for yield compression: Second, we assume that the first successful OpCo equity purchase and delivery on growth in FYsixteen serves to jump start the MLP, resulting in a degree of yield compression.
percent yield in FYsixteen, CPPL's yield compresses by one hundred bps in FY seventeen to levels that we expect other top tier growers will trade at.

Equity needs will continue to be overhang until it gets done, but we think company has some levers it can pull to lower the amount next year: Third, we have reduced the level of equity issuances we have assumed for next year to ~ dollar seven hundred sixty five million, from dollar one.one billion previously.
By our calculations, anything materially less would force leverage above five.x,
and require even higher equity needs across the two thousand seventeen two thousand eighteen timeframe in order to keep leverage in check.

We are already sensitive to concerns about the market depth required for the level of equity issuances that the partnership needs to achieve, and believe that backloading issuances would further contribute to an overhang on the units.

Parent is the most likely candidate to take back the units: With market depth a key consideration in the company's equity issuance plans, at this point in time we think it is more likely than not that instead of placing all of the incremental CPPL units into the public market, a material portion will be purchased by CPGX, who in turn would need to complete its own equity raise to support the transaction.
The investor base for CPGX is wider, and the shares are more liquid.
While we view this as the most likely scenario, we have not yet incorporated the issuance of additional CPGX equity into our forecasts.

On a standalone basis, the potentiality of CPPL purchasing its first incremental equity interest in OpCo at a discounted multiple would be a net negative for CPGX, whose stake is being diluted down at below market price.

However, by purchasing some/all of the CPPL units issued to support such a transaction, a portion of the attractive economics and cash flow made available to CPPL will be recycled back to CPGX shareholders, helping to offset terms that at face value appear unfavorable to CPGX.
We lower our price target for CPPL to dollar twenty, based on our FYsixteene distribution of dollar .eighty/unit and a target yield of four.

We are also lowering our price target for CPGX to dollar twenty four, based on a sum of the parts analysis comprised of dollar five.eight billion for OpCo, dollar nine hundred thirty six million from CPGX's LP interest in CPPL, and dollar four.two billion for the GP/IDRs, which totals dollar ten.nine billion, less estimated debt of dollar three.four billion, divided by three hundred seventeen.six million shares.

U.S. Diversified Natural Gas Industry View: NEUTRAL Stock Rating: EQUAL WEIGHT two thousand fourteenA two thousand fifteenE two thousand sixteenE two thousand seventeenE N/A forty seven forty seven forty seven N/A .thirty

six N/A sixteen thirty seven forty five N/A one eleven sixteen thirty eight fifty six N/A N/A two hundred twenty nine four hundred twenty one three hundred ninety eight N/A two hundred forty six four hundred fifty nine four hundred fifty four N/A two hundred two three hundred thirty nine three hundred seven .six one.one
We rate CPGX Equal Weight due to its levered balance sheet, which will inhibit it from paying out all of its cash flow via dividend, and instead reinvest a portion into new projects.
Dividend growth will likely accelerate through the years, but we estimate will only be six.
percent in two thousand sixteen and ten percent in two thousand seventeen before moving higher.

If we were to assume one hundredx for the GP in two thousand eighteen, which would be more in line with what the valuations of other publicly traded GPs in the year the IDRs hit the fifty percent splits were, we estimate a value of ~ dollar twenty six.

If we assume the MLP has difficulty achieving the twenty percent growth because of capital market restrictions and continues to trade around dollar fifteen/uinit, and further assume that the multiple applied to the GP comes down to sixty fivex, we estimate the stock could trade to dollar twenty.

Selected operating and Financial metrics CPPL units owned CPPL distribution per unit Total cash flow from LP distributions GP distributions/IDRs Cash distributions received from CPPL Pro rata distribution from OpCo DCF Total cash received by CPGX Cash available for distribution by CPGX CAD per share Diluted shares Coverage Total debt
U.S. MLPs Industry View: NEUTRAL Stock Rating: OVERWEIGHT CAGR thirteen.seven
We rate CPPL with an Overweight rating as we think the recent stock sell off tied to the equity overhang has been overdone.
CPPL has a robust backlog of projects that will support twenty percent distribution growth through at least two thousand nineteen with minimal commodity and volume exposure .
Our upside case of dollar twenty three is predicated on the same two thousand sixteene distribution as our base case, except assumes a three.five
Our downside case of dollar thirteen is predicated on the same two thousand sixteene distribution as our base case, except assumes a six.

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.

Guide to the Barclays Research Price Target: Each analyst has a single price target on the stocks that they cover.
The price target represents that analyst's expectation of where the stock will trade in the next twelve months.

Top Picks: Barclays Equity Research's Top Picks represent the single best alpha generating investment idea within each industry, taken from among the Overweight rated stocks within that industry.
Barclays Equity Research publishes global and regional Top Picks reports every quarter and analysts may also publish intra quarter changes to their Top Picks, as necessary.
While analysts may highlight other Overweight rated stocks in their published research in addition to their Top Pick, there can only be one Top Pick for each industry.
